title: Keyword-only arguments (PEP 3102): making calls clearer with '*'
content:
Keyword-only arguments are parameters that **must** be supplied by name. They help avoid ambiguous calls and make code self-documenting.

In a function definition, putting a bare `*` means: “everything after this is keyword-only.”

---
## 1) Basic keyword-only example

```python
def connect(host, port, *, timeout=5):
    return f"connect {host}:{port} timeout={timeout}"

print(connect("example.com", 443, timeout=10))
# connect("example.com", 443, 10) fails because timeout is keyword-only
```

---
## 2) Why keyword-only is useful
Consider a function with many optional settings. Keyword-only prevents calls like:

```python
# confusing
# connect("example.com", 443, 10)

# clearer
connect("example.com", 443, timeout=10)
```

---
## 3) Combining normal args + keyword-only args

```python
def draw(text, width=10, *, fill="-", align="center"):
    if len(text) >= width:
        return text

    pad = width - len(text)
    if align == "left":
        return text + fill * pad
    if align == "right":
        return fill * pad + text

    left = pad // 2
    right = pad - left
    return fill * left + text + fill * right

print(draw("hi", 12, fill="*", align="left"))
print(draw("hi", 12, fill="*", align="right"))
print(draw("hi", 12, fill="*"))
```

---
## 4) Practice: make a function safer by forcing named options

```python
def parse_int(text, *, base=10):
    text = text.strip()
    try:
        return int(text, base)
    except ValueError:
        return None

print(parse_int("FF", base=16))
print(parse_int(" 42 "))
```
